awd_titl_txt: Achieve Career Success in Science through Excellence (ACSScellence)
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project at the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP) will provide scholarships for low-income, talented students with demonstrated financial need pursuing bachelor's degrees in science and mathematics. The Achieve Career Success in Science through Excellence (ACSScellence) program will provide scholarships for low-income undergraduate students and engage them in a program designed for the type of challenges low-income students will face while in college and after attaining their degree.  Participants will be students who are enrolling as freshmen in UTEP or who are transferring. The program will improve student success and persistence to degree completion and will prepare scholars to become innovative STEM professionals. In addition to financial support, the program implements a multi-level mentoring system that includes internal and external mentors and student engagement in multiple curricular and co-curricular activities. Scholarships and support for academically strong students, who may not otherwise be able to afford college, will help to produce a well-trained workforce that will contribute to the economic vitality of the Texas and the nation.

The project will include a study of the impact that specific program activities will have on student success. The unique demographics of UTEP's undergraduate student population (82.5% Hispanic) offers an opportunity to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions on low-income minorities currently underrepresented in STEM, and thus contribute to the design of effective strategies to narrow the underrepresentation gap.  Student support activities include faculty mentoring and monthly mentoring meetings with STEM professionals external to the institution.  Students will be enrolled in research-intensive courses and in a course to foster innovative thinking.  Career development support includes participation in professional skills development workshops, external internships, and engagement in a research project through a capstone course. These activities will help the low-income students to successfully complete a STEM degree in a timely manner while developing the professional competencies and mindset required for successful careers in the 21st century science and technology workforce.  The findings from the program will be disseminated widely to the STEM education community and help to increase understanding of the attributes and practices of successful student scholarship and support programs.

inst.inst_name: University of Texas at El Paso
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT EL PASO

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Texas at El Paso

por.por_cntn:
The Achieve Career Success in Science through Excellence (ACSScellence) program provided scholarships for financially disadvantaged undergraduate students pursuing STEM degrees at the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP) and engaged them in a program specifically designed for the type of challenges they would potentially face while in college and after attaining their degree. The program sought to improve student success towards degree completion and prepare scholars to become innovative STEM professionals through numerous activities.

ACSScellence provided students financial support, as well as several extra-curricular activities. These activities included: mentored research experiences, bi-weekly meetings with the program directors, professional development workshops, and research/internships external to UTEP. At the same time, an external evaluation team monitored scholars' progress, which helped inform program directors on improving the program and activities.

Overall, ACSScellence supported 37 students over five years. Of the 37 who participated in the program, 27 completed their undergraduate programs and graduated with bachelor's degrees in science. Among program scholars, 34 of 37 reported belonging to a group traditionally underrepresented in STEM, including women (22 scholars) and minorities (3 American Indian/Alaska Native, 2 Black or African American, 29 Hispanic or Latino). Through the evaluation, scholars reported a positive impact from their participation in the program, including increased confidence and interest in pursuing further education in STEM and encouraging them to pursue a future career in STEM.

All 37 scholars presented their research results at local symposia, ten scholars presented at 16 national conferences, and four published their work in 5 scientific journals as undergraduates. Many (37%) have continued their STEM educations after graduation. Six students are currently enrolled in STEM Ph.D. programs, five in master's programs, and one is in medical school. Two alumni are obtaining second bachelor's degrees, and the remaining are preparing applications for graduate programs for admittance during the 2022-2023 academic year.

The scholarships offered benefited a population of students who have traditionally needed to hold a part-time or full-time job to help fund their education. Lack of financial resources can make students prolong their graduation date and, in some cases, drop out of school because of economic hardships. By participating in research projects, professional development workshops, and other activities in the program, undergraduate fellows have made substantial professional and personal gains and have acquired critical transferable skills. In comparison to their counterparts, program scholars reported being more comfortable applying knowledge to research work and developing skills related to research. Fellows also indicated higher levels of engagement in attitudes and behaviors of a researcher.

The ACSScellence program is helping promote and enhance our students' interest in pursuing advanced degrees, their professional identities, and their attitudes about learning science. These findings contribute to the knowledge and development of similar programs in other STEM disciplines while successfully contributing to the diversification of STEM fields.


Last Modified: 11/24/2021
Modified by: Karina C Canaba
